facts.text: In 1961 Ravi Datt Joshi was the Assistant District Inspector of Schools at Karnal and the appellant was working under him as a clerk.
Between March to December 1961, Joshi authorised the appellant to draw certain amounts from the State Bank of India, Karnal.
On March 11, 1961, the appellant drew Rs. 979.12 for payment to M/s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons. None of these amounts was paid to any of the aforesaid persons.

On March 31, 1961, he drew a further sum of Rs. 1449.38 out of which Rs. 1404 were to be paid to the Indian Red Cross Society. He made an entry in the cash book showing as if that amount was paid to the said Society and got that entry initialled by Joshi.

On July 3, 1961, he encashed a bill for Rs. 424, the amount being payable to two teachers, Ishwar Datt and Chand Ram. The appellant made an entry in the acquittance roll showing as if he had paid Rs. 200 to Chand Ram.
On November 15, 1961 he received Rs. 281.15 in respect of arrears of salary of one teacher, Harbhajan Kaur.

On December 2, 1961, he received Rs. 42.66 and Rs. 494, the first amount being the salary of Ram Sarup, another teacher and the other as contingent fund payable to the staff. None of these amounts was paid.

On complaint by M/s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons to Joshi that the amount due to them was not paid, Joshi looked into the matter and finding that that amount and other amounts were embezzled, he lodged a complaint before the Police.
The police registered a case under s. 409 against the appellant and under ss. 409, 465, 477-A and s. 120-B of the Penal Code against Joshi.

The trial Magistrate convicted Joshi and the appellant under s. 120-B and under s. 409 for criminal breach of trust in respect of Rs. 3414.53 and also under s. 477-A and awarded different sentences and fines directing the sentences to run concurrently.
In appeal, the Additional Sessions Judge acquitted Joshi of all the charges. He also acquitted the appellant on charges under s. 120-B and s. 477-A but upheld his conviction under s. 409.

The appellant filed a revision in the Punjab High Court where he conceded that the aforesaid amounts were received by him from the Bank but pleaded that he had handed them over to Joshi and that it was Joshi's duty to disburse those amounts and to maintain accounts as Joshi was incharge of the office.

The High Court held that the said moneys having been admittedly received by the appellant, the burden of proof was upon him to show what he had done with them, that there being no evidence that he handed them over to Joshi except his bare allegation, the appellant had failed to discharge the burden and was, therefore, rightly convicted under s. 409.

The High Court relied upon the evidence of Sukhminder Singh, the District Inspector of Schools that the appellant had confessed before him that out of the said sum of Rs. 3414-53 he had misappropriated Rs. 2500 and that Joshi had misappropriated the balance of Rs. 979 and that the appellant was prepared to deposit the amount of Rs. 2500.

Evidence showed that when approached for payment, the appellant had falsely represented to M/s. Joti Pershad Gupta Sons and the Assistant Secretary of the Red Cross Society that he had remitted to them the two amounts payable to them.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1963 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 824 of 1963.
Appellant applied for production of certain documents in trial: Memo dated June 27, 1960; Instructions 1962; Bill book; remittance transfer register; sub-voucher for Rs. 494.
In his statement under s. 342 CrPC, appellant admitted drawing amounts from Bank, said handed to Joshi, made entries in remittance transfer register at Joshi's instance.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in placing the burden on appellant to prove he handed over moneys to Joshi beyond reasonable doubt.
Whether appellant was prejudiced by non-production of documents he called for.
Whether entrustment was in appellant's capacity as public servant for s.409 IPC.
Whether conviction under s.409 simpliciter valid without separate charge, when charged under s.409 r/w s.120B.
Whether lack of sanction u/s 196A(2) CrPC for charges u/s 120B and 477A vitiates trial.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in proceeding as if appellant had to prove his case beyond reasonable doubt that he handed over moneys to Joshi. Relied on Woolmington v. Director of Public Prosecutions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Woolmington v. Director of Public Prosecutions (1935 AC 462)

petitioner_arguments.text: Could have raised doubt if documents produced; application rejected, prejudiced.
Not his duty as clerk to receive moneys; received at Joshi's instance; not entrusted in capacity as public servant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Budha Lal v. State of Rajasthan

petitioner_arguments.text: No charge under s.409 simpliciter, only r/w s.120B; conspiracy failed, cannot convict under s.409 alone.
Misjoinder of charges: six items misappropriation, three falsification entries.
No sanction u/s 196A(2) CrPC for s.120B and s.477A; trial vitiated.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Abdul Mian v. King (AIR 1951 Pat 513); Govindram Sunder Das v. Emperor (AIR 1942 Sind 63)

court_reasoning.text: No question of reasonable doubt due to appellant's admission of receipt, confession of misappropriating Rs.2500, false representations. Documents: some produced/admitted, others not traceable or irrelevant; no objection raised timely; no RTR possible as moneys not remitted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant failed to discharge burden; extra-judicial confession and false representations prove guilt.

court_reasoning.text: Even if Joshi disbursing authority, appellant confessed misappropriation. Documents not produced not prejudicial.
Appellant public servant; evidence he received and disbursed moneys; authorised by Joshi for express purpose of payment. Not raised in HC. Budha Lal distinguished.
Court can convict under substantive charge even if conspiracy fails. No prejudice. Kizhakeppallik Moosa contrary to Willie Slaney.
No earlier objection to misjoinder; no prejudice shown.
Lack of sanction affects only s.120B charge; trial on s.409 proceeds as it requires no sanction. No prejudice due to confession. Cited cases support severability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Absence of sanction does not vitiate substantive charge under s.409.

holdings.text: Burden on accused to explain admitted entrustment; failed due to confession and conduct.
No prejudice from non-production of documents.
Entrustment to appellant as public servant for specific purpose constitutes s.409.
Conviction under s.409 valid despite failure on s.120B.
No sanction for s.120B does not vitiate trial on s.409.

precedents_cited.relevance: Conviction on substantive charge despite conspiracy failure.
Contrary to Supreme Court view on charges.
Sanction condition precedent for single charge.
No cognizance without sanction for conspiracy.
Trial proceeds on substantive offence sans sanction for conspiracy.
Conviction on other charges despite no sanction for conspiracy.
Inquiry on offences not needing sanction.
Prejudice from conspiracy evidence vitiated other charges.
Trial on substantive offence despite no sanction for conspiracy.

statutes_cited.relevance: Charges for criminal breach of trust, forgery, falsification of accounts, conspiracy.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court found no substance in any of the appellant's contentions, upheld the conviction under s.409 IPC by the trial court, Sessions Judge and High Court, and dismissed the appeal by special leave.

key_quotes.text: "the burden of proof was upon him to show what he had done with them, that there being no evidence that he handed them over to Joshi except his bare allegation, the appellant had failed to discharge the burden"
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court reasoning on burden upheld by SC.

key_quotes.speaker: court
